importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The span from 2008 to 2025 represents the timeline of crimes, investigations, and legal proceedings, including the decades-long evasion of justice through aliasing and false death claims.

keyTakeAways: Nicholas Rossi, a 38-year-old man, was convicted of raping two women in northern Utah in 2008.
Rossi allegedly faked his death in 2020 by publishing an online obituary claiming he died of non-Hodgkin lymphoma, which authorities later disputed.
Rossi fled the U.S., appearing in Scotland in 2021 while receiving treatment for COVID-19, where hospital staff identified him via tattoos linked to an Interpol notice.
He was extradited to Utah in January 2024 after a prolonged legal battle and multiple alias claims, including identifying himself as Arthur Knight, an Irish orphan.
Utah authorities used a decade-old DNA rape kit from 2008 to identify Rossi, part of a broader initiative to clear rape kit backlogs.
The victim in the first case testified that Rossi pressured her to pay for expenses, took on debt for engagement rings, and raped her in his bedroom after their engagement.
Rossi was convicted in August 2025 in the first rape case and sentenced to five years to life in prison; sentencing in the second case is scheduled for November 4, 2025.
The judge described Rossi as a 'serial abuser of women' and a 'flight risk,' emphasizing the danger he posed to public safety.
He has a history of evading justice, previously being wanted in Rhode Island for failing to register as a sex offender and facing fraud charges in Ohio.
The case underscores the importance of DNA database utilization and international cooperation in solving crimes involving flight risks and false identity claims.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A Utah judge sentenced Nicholas Rossi, a 38-year-old man, to five years to life in prison for raping two women in northern Utah in 2008. Rossi, who had previously fled the U.S. and falsely claimed to have died in 2020, was identified through a decade-old DNA rape kit and later arrested in Scotland via Interpol notice after hospital staff recognized his tattoos. The case highlights his pattern of deception, including using aliases such as Arthur Knight and falsely claiming to be an Irish orphan, as well as his history of evading justice in Rhode Island and facing fraud charges in Ohio. The victim described the abuse and financial coercion, and the judge emphasized Rossi's danger to public safety as a 'serial abuser and flight risk.' The case underscores the role of DNA backlogs, international cooperation, and the importance of accountability in sexual violence cases.
title: Man accused of faking his own death and fleeing the US after rape charges gets at least five years in prison
